Let's follow up now on an explosion at the Imperial Sugar Refinery in Port Wentworth, Georgia; happened two weeks ago.
The fire in the plant just outside Savannah burned for seven days.
Federal investigators are on the scene and this week funerals were held for the last of nine employees who died as a result of the explosion.
NPR's Kathy Lohr reports.
The Imperial Sugar Company sits back off Georgia Highway 25, part of a string of industrial plants that sprang up along the Savannah River.
Pines, oaks and even palm trees line this stretch of road, heavily traveled by semi-trucks.
The sugar plant, which opened in 1917, is all but hidden from the highway.
On February 7th at about 7:00 in the evening, the peace in Port Wentworth was shattered.
It was just one big very deep boom.
Father Michael Cavanaugh is pastor of Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church just across the street from the plant.
Initially this is where everyone ended up.
And so we set up the front as a more serious triage area.
We brought tables out.
They were hanging the saline bottles from the pear trees in front of the church.
Eight died in the explosion, dozens were injured, and one worker died later in the hospital.
Sixteen people still remain hospitalized with extensive burns.
Sam Boyd has worked at the sugar plant for 26 years.
He was off that night after he and a co-worker traded shifts.
It's hard to say.
I feel guilty in a way and glad in a way, you know.
I wanted to go in there and see if I could get, you know, some more out.
Boyd stayed outside the plant all that night to help the injured, among them many of his friends.
He says he's still in shock over the explosion.
I tried to go to sleep last night and I didn't do nothing but toss and turn.
And I went to the doctor the other day and he gave me something to help me sleep and I had to take one of them.
It doesn't seem to help any.
I just sit there and toss and turn.
The fire raged in the silos for a week and burned up to 4,000 degrees.
When it was out, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives came in to conduct its investigation and found no criminal wrongdoing.
Officials say sugar dust is the likely cause.
President and CEO of Imperial Sugar John Sheptor says it's still too early to know for sure.
